description: From Middle English don, from Old English dōn, from Proto-West Germanic *dōn, from Proto-Germanic *dōną, from Proto-Indo-European *dʰeh₁- (“to put, place, do, make”).
For senses 4 and 5, compare Old Norse duga, whence Danish du.

The past tense form is from Middle English didde, dude, from Old English dyde, *diede, an unexpected development from Proto-Germanic *dedǭ/*dedē (the expected reflex would be *ded), from Proto-Indo-European *dʰédʰeh₁ti, an athematic e-reduplicated verb of the same root *dʰeh₁-.

The obligatory, meaningless use of do in interrogative, negative, and—formerly—affirmative sentences, existing in some form in most Germanic languages, is thought by some linguists to be one of the Brittonicisms in English, calqued from Brythonic. It is first recorded in Middle English, where it may have marked the perfective aspect, though in some cases the meaning seems to be imperfective. In Early Modern English, any meaning in such contexts was lost, making it a dummy auxiliary, and soon thereafter its use became mandatory in most questions and negations.
Doublets include deed, deem, -dom, but not deal.

Other cognates include, via Latin, English feast, festival, fair (“celebration”), via Greek, English theo-, theme, thesis, and Sanskrit दधाति (dadhāti, “to put”), धातृ (dhātṛ, “creator”) and धातु (dhātu, “layer, element, root”).

nouns.description: do (plural dos or do's or (uncommon) doos)

entries.meaning: (UK, informal) A party, celebration, social function; usually of moderate size and formality.
examples: Synonyms: get-together, see also Thesaurus:party
We’re having a bit of a do on Saturday to celebrate my birthday.

entries.meaning: (informal) Clipping of hairdo.
examples: Alternative form: 'do
Nice do!
I don't like to spend time on my hairstyle, so I usually just wear a do-rag.

entries.meaning: (chiefly fossilized) Something that can or should be done.
examples: Don't forget the dos and don'ts.
Antonym: don't

entries.meaning: (chiefly obsolete, fossilized in the UK) Something that has been done.
examples: "How come you quit?" "I'm moving to London." "Fair dos."

entries.meaning: (archaic) Ado; bustle; stir; to-do; A period of confusion or argument.
examples: Synonym: to-do

entries.meaning: (obsolete, UK, slang) A cheat; a swindler.
(obsolete, UK, slang) An act of swindling; a fraud or deception.
(UK, slang) A homicide.

verbs.description: do (third-person singular simple present does, present participle doing, simple past did, past participle done)

entries.meaning: (auxiliary) A syntactic marker in a question whose main verb is not another auxiliary verb or be.
examples: Do you go there often?

entries.meaning: (auxiliary) A syntactic marker in negations with the indicative and imperative moods.
examples: I do not go there often.
Do not listen to him.

entries.meaning: (auxiliary) A syntactic marker for emphasis with the indicative, imperative, and subjunctive moods.
examples: But I do go sometimes.
Do tell us.

entries.meaning: (pro-verb) A syntactic marker that refers back to an earlier verb and allows the speaker to avoid repeating the verb; in most dialects, not used with auxiliaries such as be, though it can be in AAVE.
examples: I play tennis; she does too.
(nonstandard) They don't think it be like it is, but it do.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To perform; to execute.
examples: Synonyms: accomplish, carry out, functionate
All you ever do is surf the Internet. What will you do this afternoon?

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To cause, make (someone) (do something).
(intransitive, transitive) To suffice.
examples: it’s not the best broom, but it will have to do;  this will do me, thanks.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be reasonable or acceptable.
examples: It simply will not do to have dozens of children running around such a quiet event.

entries.meaning: (ditransitive) To have (as an effect).
examples: The fresh air did him some good.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To fare, perform (well or poorly).
examples: Our relationship isn't doing very well;  how do you do?

entries.meaning: (transitive, chiefly in questions) To have as one's job.
examples: What does Bob do? — He's a plumber.

entries.meaning: To perform the tasks or actions associated with (something).
examples: "Don't forget to do your report" means something quite different depending on whether you're a student or a programmer.

entries.meaning: To cook.
examples: Synonyms: see Thesaurus:cook
I'll just do some eggs.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To travel in, to tour, to make a circuit of.
examples: Let’s do New York also.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To treat in a certain way.
(transitive) To work for or on, by way of caring for, looking after, preparing, cleaning, keeping in order, etc.
(intransitive, obsolete) To act or behave in a certain manner; to conduct oneself.
(transitive) To spend (time) in jail. (See also do time)
examples: Synonym: serve
I did five years for armed robbery.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To impersonate or depict.
examples: Synonyms: imitate, personate, take off
They really laughed when he did Clinton, with a perfect accent and a leer.

entries.meaning: (with 'a' and the name of a person, place, event, etc.) To copy or emulate the actions or behaviour that is associated with the person or thing mentioned.
examples: He did a Henry VIII and got married six times.
He was planning to do a 9/11.

entries.meaning: (transitive, slang) To kill.
examples: Synonyms: do in, murder, off, rub out, see also Thesaurus:kill

entries.meaning: (transitive, slang) To deal with for good and all; to finish up; to undo; to ruin; to do for.
examples: Sometimes they lie in wait in these dark streets, and fracture his skull,  […]  or break his arm, or cut the sinew of his wrist; and that they call doing him.

entries.meaning: (informal) To punish for a misdemeanor.
examples: He got done for speeding.
Teacher'll do you for that!

entries.meaning: (transitive, slang) To have sex with. (See also do it)
examples: Synonyms: go to bed with, sleep with, see also Thesaurus:copulate with

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cheat or swindle.
examples: Synonyms: defraud, diddle, mug off, rip off, scam, see also Thesaurus:deceive
That guy just did me out of two hundred bucks!

entries.meaning: (transitive) To convert into a certain form; especially, to translate.
examples: the novel has just been done into English;  I'm going to do this play into a movie

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To finish.
(archaic, dialectal, transitive, auxiliary) Used to form the present progressive of verbs.
(stock exchange) To cash or to advance money for, as a bill or note.
(informal, transitive, ditransitive) To make or provide.
examples: Synonyms: furnish, give, supply, see also Thesaurus:give
Do they do haircuts there?
Could you do me a burger with mayonnaise instead of ketchup?

entries.meaning: (informal, transitive) To injure (one's own body part).
examples: "Defender Kolo Toure admitted Given will be a loss, but gave his backing to Nielsen. 'I think he's done his shoulder,' said the Ivorian."

entries.meaning: (transitive) To take drugs.
examples: I do cocaine.

entries.meaning: (transitive, in the form be doing [somewhere]) To exist with a purpose or for a reason.
examples: What's that car doing in our swimming pool?

description: From the name of musicologist Giovanni Battista Doni, who suggested replacing the original ut with an open syllable for ease of singing. First found in Italian.

entries.meaning: (music) A syllable used in solfège to represent the first and eighth tonic of a major scale.
examples: Synonym: (archaic) ut

entries.meaning: (archaic) Abbreviation of ditto.
